like drive around the block a couple times if my interview is at three I'm getting like to the area at like 2:30 uh
I'm going to the lobby at like 2:45 just to make sure that there's nothing that's going to keep me from being there or

because like there are reasons why you might be late but it's almost always a bad impression so that that's the one

when you were young that's very true being late is just a a bad look so to
increase your chance of having that first five minutes go your way make sure
that you're there at like second zero the other thing that I'm going to say about making sure that you use that
first five minutes is when someone asks you a question maybe because you're
nervous you may want to give a very full throated lengthy answer and often it's
better to be concise because I've been the interviewer where I'm asking someone a question and it's like the second

question and like it's always okay to like give like a direct answer to the

no I'm good I got what I need and that's something that most people don't know is that the interviewer is usually going

your background what you bring to the table and so by going on and on and on
in an answer you're not showing that you respect interviewer's time nor Shing that you understand how to manage a

production and I worked on this many features that's all well and good but
most hiring managers we're not looking for activity we're looking for impact
what impact did you have on the teams that you worked on you can have a lot of

customers we hire people to have impact not to Simply have
activity now one thing that I've championed because I've been a hiring manager and
I've interviewed people from multiple countries and I've worked at a lot of global companies is I've pushed for
making the interview questions public because most companies interview questions are in a repository or you
know walled off from public View and I understand reasons that people do that
but I've always felt that having the interview questions be private really does a disservice to two to two groups
of people one there are some people when you ask them a question they can come
right back at you with a great answer right they're quick on their feet they really have a good way of explaining
what they've done and coming off the cuff is really easy there are other
people and I'm one of them where I need time to process I need time to think
about my answer to the question because like you just asked me a question out of the blue you're a stranger I'm feeling

before remote work was the thing right so I go back to the parking garage get

to show something that we really don't use in the day-to-day work so that's the
